title: 110_s1987
content: Tax-exempt financing for alternative motor vehicle facilities is addressed in Section 1. Tax-exempt financing for alternative motor vehicle facilities is addressed in Section 1, which includes amending the Internal Revenue Code to define an "alternative motor vehicle facility" as an automobile development and production facility built before 1981 that is retrofitted or reconstructed using financing from the net proceeds of the issue. The Internal Revenue Code allows tax-exempt financing for alternative motor vehicle facilities that are retrofitted or reconstructed for the production of qualified alternative motor vehicles or component parts. The total allocation by the Secretary is limited to $12 billion, with a maximum of $4 billion per taxpayer. The Secretary allocates funds among State or local governments for alternative motor vehicle facilities based on set limits. The Secretary allocates funds for alternative motor vehicle facilities based on set limits, with special rules requiring at least 95 percent of proceeds from bond sales to be spent on facilities within a 5-year period. Requests for extension can be granted if reasonable cause is shown. The issuer must spend at least 95 percent of bond proceeds within 5 years, or redeem bonds with unspent proceeds within 90 days. Exception for current refunding bonds with specific maturity date requirements. The amendments made by this section apply to bonds issued after December 31, 2007, and before January 1, 2013. Section 146(g)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new provision. The refunding bond must not exceed the outstanding amount of the refunded bond and the refunded bond must be redeemed within 90 days of the issuance of the refunding bond.
